GameSequence.Clue: This crustacean excretes one of the strongest natural adhesives in the world in order to stick to rocks, piers, ships, and even animals like whales.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This crustacean has a shell-like covering made up of chitin and calcium plates, which give them a protective rigid structure.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Barnacle colonies growing on the hulls of ships actually create huge environmental and economic impact. Barnacle growth can increase the weight and drag of a ship in the water by as much as 60%, increasing fuel usage by as much as 40%! However, barnacles are not all bad, they are important intertidal species! Fossilized barnacles that used to hitch a ride on the backs of humpback and gray whales have been used to help reconstruct ancient migration patterns of whale populations millions of years ago and help us compare migration patterns of whales today.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by James St. John. Uploaded August 29, 2009. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Barnacles_encrusting_wood_(Cayo_Costa_Island,_Florida,_USA)_2_(26353425635).jpg

GameSequence.Clue: This ocean dwelling animal is unlike other fish, it only has one singular continuous fin and does not have gill covers, so to breath it must constantly open and close its mouth.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This ocean dwelling animal is a long, slim snakelike fish.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: California Moray Eels have a second set of jaws in their throat that extend forward to grab prey with backwards facing teeth that drag the prey back into the throat. This second set of jaws is called pharyngeal jaws. They use this feeding method to mainly eat fish, but also feed on octopus, lobsters and shrimp in the rocky reefs of southern California.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Yury Velikanau. Uploaded October 23, 2016. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:California_Moray_Eel_(32582219365).jpg

GameSequence.Clue: This brush-like alternative to teeth is used by large mammals to filter food like plankton, fish and krill out of ocean water.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This brush-like structure is black and wiry in appearance.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Baleen is made out of keratin, the same material that makes up our hair and fingernails. Baleen whales open their mouths wide and expand their throats like a balloon to gulp in huge amounts of seawater and food, then expel the water through their balene, filtering out food to swallow.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Dr. Brandon Southall, NMFS/OPR. Taken on November 10, 2010. https://www.flickr.com/photos/noaaphotolib/5187319399

GameSequence.Clue: This now extinct cephalopod resembles modern nautilus and was an abundant predator in the warm shallow sea that covered California 200 million years ago.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This extinct cephalopod had a tightly wound shell.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Previously, one of the explanations for these tightly wound shells was that they were actually coiled-up snakes that turned to stone, earning ammonites the nickname “snake-stones” - but we now know ammonites are not reptiles at all, but cephalopods (the group that includes squids, octopus, cuttlefish, nautilus and ammonites). They believe that ammonites were similar to modern day octopus with 8 arms, but with a shell similar to a nautilus.
GameSequence.Credit: Image created by the DataBase Center for Life Science. Created August, 2010. https://doi.org/10.7875/togopic.2020.08

GameSequence.Clue: This charming creature is the state bird of California!
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: These birds have a ‘topknot’ or head plume made of six overlapping feathers that form the shape of an apostrophe.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Often you will find California Quail running along the ground from one bush to another where they find cover. They are social birds and are primarily found in  groups called a covey.
GameSequence.Credit: "Quail on the Rail" by Anita Ritenour. Uploaded April 7, 2018. https://www.flickr.com/photos/puliarfanita/27453562628

GameSequence.Clue: This small but fierce predator found in ponds and marshes can breathe through its butt! It can also carry air bubbles under its wings that it slowly absorbs while diving underwater.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: While it is ‘giant’ in comparison to many other bugs, these bugs in California are still only slightly larger than the size of an adult's thumb.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Their bites are very painful, but they won’t kill a human at least… Giant water bugs pierce their prey with a poisonous beak and can kill an animal 50 times its own size with its deadly toxins. Their toxins will slowly paralyze and liquify their prey from the inside out. If you’re looking to avoid getting pinched by these giant water bugs simply avoid hiking barefoot near the freshwater streams in the Santa Monica Mountains. Though their pinch seems scary, their method of parental care is fascinating. During mating season males will carry the fertilized eggs and care for the young after hatching while females will continue to find different mates.
GameSequence.Credit: Image created by the DataBase Center for Life Science. Created August, 2010. https://doi.org/10.7875/togopic.2020.08

GameSequence.Clue: This desert dwelling animal can run surprisingly fast, reaching speeds of 15 miles per hour when pursuing prey.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This bird was famously represented in cartoons as the nemesis of a rather wily coyote.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Unlike depicted in cartoons, Greater Roadrunners cannot run faster than a coyote, but they’re still very fast runners! As opportunistic omnivores (animals that will eat both plants and other animals) roadrunners eat almost anything on the ground, including venomous rattlesnakes and scorpions. When eating rattlesnakes, they will team up and repeatedly peck at the head. For larger prey they will slam it against a rock to make it easier to swallow.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Andrej Chudy. Taken on May 4, 2017. https://www.flickr.com/photos/76362620@N00/34435311504

GameSequence.Clue: This curious and expressive tree dwelling animal uses tail flicking to communicate, in addition to several different vocalizations.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This mammal has a great bushy grey tail.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Unlike the social introduced fox squirrels, western gray squirrels are actually fairly shy and will run up trees and chirp at you if you are to disturb them. Unfortunately the loss of mature oak and pine forests, road-kill mortality and competition from the more aggressive fox squirrels has caused western gray squirrel populations to decline and they are now extirpated (extinct in a given regions) in some areas of California. To help conserve these unique creatures we need to work together to maintain high quality oak woodlands and pine forests through better fire management strategies and decreasing urban sprawl.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Fish Demon. Uploaded on March 9, 2010. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:WesternGraySquirrel1.jpg

GameSequence.Clue: This tree blooms in long sprays of white flowers that are often seen buzzing with pollinators like bees and butterflies.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: When the seeds of this plant begin to split open their leathery casing, they resemble the eye of a male deer.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: This California native plant is one of the first to leaf out in the spring, and one of the first to lose its foliage, which allows it to avoid the worst of the summer heat. Buckeye seeds contain poisonous compounds that evolved to deter predators from eating them.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by John Morgan. Taken on November 25, 2007. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Aesculus_californica_Mount_Diablo.jpg

GameSequence.Clue: This slimy detrivore spends its time moving slowly through damp redwood forests, eating moss, dead plants, and even animal scat, digesting it, and pooping out nutrient rich soil!
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This detritivore is yellow in appearance.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: There is a long tradition of people picking up banana slugs and kissing them for good luck. And who wouldn’t want to kiss one of these charming critters? But it’s best to leave slugs alone as sweat and contaminants on your skin can be absorbed through the slug’s porous skin, which can be harmful to their health. Banana slug slime is neither solid, nor liquid, but instead is a form of liquid crystal! This fascinating slime can absorb 100 times its weight in water from whatever it touches, and facilitates the transfer of chemicals and nutrients directly into the slugs organs. Scientists have been researching ways to create and use a similar material in place of stitches! The banana slug is the beloved, self-chosen mascot of UC Santa Cruz...GO SLUGS!
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Iamnotabunny. Taken on June 18, 2019. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Banana_slug_moving.jpg

GameSequence.Clue: This giant Pleistocene mammal roamed California until the most recent mass extinction around 13,000 years ago.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: On display here at Lindsay Wildlife Experience we have a small piece of this extinct animal’s tusk on display.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Even animals as large as mammoths need a way to scratch their itches. One such grooming technique was to rub up against large boulders and rocky outcroppings. You can see several such rubbing rocks or mammoth rocks along the Sonoma County coast. These rocky outcrops have patches that were polished smooth by the repeated rubbing of mammoths bodies against the rock surface. The appearance and scratch patterns on these ancient mammoth rocks match perfectly with rubbing rocks used by modern elephants!
GameSequence.Credit: Display at the Royal BC Museum in Victoria (Canada). Photo by Flickr user Flying Puffin. Taken on July 1, 2011. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Woolly_mammoth.jpg

GameSequence.Clue: This mammal requires loose soil so they can excavate an appropriate burrow where adults will hibernate through both fall and winter.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This mammal has a mix of gray and brown fur and often are found scurrying along the ground.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: California ground squirrels inhabit many different habitat types ranging from fields to woodlands, the only habitat they don’t use is deserts where the soil is too loose for them to make a burrow! If you see California Ground Squirrels aboveground in the fall and winter those will only be young squirrels as the adults hibernate during that time.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Howcheng. Taken on January 3, 2009. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:CA_Ground_Squirrel_on_rock.jpg

GameSequence.Clue: This evergreen shrub or small tree lives in California’s iconic chaparral habitat (much like what you see on Mt. Diablo) and grows in beautiful and dramatic red, brown and maroon colored twisting branches.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This evergreen shrub has green rounded leaves.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Parry’s Manzanita is a California endemic species, meaning it is found nowhere else in the world. In springtime thes shrubs grow clusters of small pinkish-white bell shaped flowers. The fruits of this species of manzanita were a food source for the native Luiseño people of Southern California.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Stan Shebs. Taken in 2006. https://calscape.org/view.php?pl=329&img=8910

GameSequence.Clue: This is the state gem of California!
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This gem is found in rocky serpentinite.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Benitoite is a rare deep blue gem that can cost you up to $3,000 per carat for a good quality gem! This gem forms in hydrothermally altered serpentine - serpentine that has had hot water circulate through it - in high pressure but low temperature environments. The highest quality of this rare gem is only found in the Benito Gem Mine in California
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Rob Lavinsky. Taken on April 25, 2010. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Benitoite-Neptunite-40041.jpg

GameSequence.Clue: This bird has a distinct hooked bill and is scavenger, meaning they don’t often kill their food, but instead eat animals that are already dead.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This bird has a characteristic featherless vulture head and is one of the largest birds in North America.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: California Condors are one of the rarest birds in the world and longest living birds in North America with a lifespan of 60 years. Their population declined to only 22 surviving individuals in 1987 leading to one of the most expensive species conservation projects in U.S. history. Some of the primary causes of their nearly extinct population was due to poaching, agricultural chemical use like DDT, lead poisoning (from ingesting lead bullets left in carcasses from hunting) and habitat destruction. In 1987, the U.S. Government captured all remaining California Condors for a captive breeding recovery program in an attempt to recover them from extinction. Though still critically endangered, captive breeding programs have helped recover California Condor populations to 175 individuals in captivity and 329 that have successfully been reintroduced into the wild (Central California and Grand Canyon in Arizona).
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Chuck Szmurlo. Taken on December 11, 2006. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:California-Condor3-Szmurlo_edit.jpg

GameSequence.Clue: This hoofed mammal lives in dry, rocky regions on steep cliffs and mountain sides. Males will fight each other on these dangerous slopes using their distinctly shaped horns.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: Their big horns are shaped like croissant rolls.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Desert bighorn sheep have specially shaped elastic hooves that allow them to easily traverse rocky, treacherous terrain. Their populations have significantly declined due to hunting and proximity to domestic livestock, which creates competition for resources and spreads disease to remaining wild herds.
GameSequence.Credit: "Desert Bighorn Sheep" by Andrew Cattoir. Taken on November 29, 2011. https://www.flickr.com/photos/lakemeadnra/8981481677/

GameSequence.Clue: This is California’s state rock, it is found on Mt. Diablo!
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This rock is an apple-green to black with mottled light and dark areas.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Though serpentine has a shiny wax-like appearance, it has a slightly soapy feel. Serpentine is found in central and northern California in the Coastal Ranges, Klamath Mountains and the Sierra Nevada foothills.
GameSequence.Credit: "Serpentine Texture" by Kevin Walsh. Taken on April 21, 2005. https://www.flickr.com/photos/86624586@N00/10194691

GameSequence.Clue: As a caterpillar this insect eats the leaves of a toxic plant called milkweed. As it undergoes metamorphosis to become a butterfly it stores those toxins and becomes poisonous to eat!
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This orange and black butterfly that migrates through California every year.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Monarch butterflies migrate from their summer breeding grounds in northeastern U.S. and Canada down to Mexico to escape the cold winter. Monarch Butterflies can travel up to 100 miles per day during their 3,000-mile migration south.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Thomas Bresson. Taken on August 31, 2009. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:ComputerHotline_-_Danaus_plexippus_(by)_(3).jpg

GameSequence.Clue: As a caterpillar this insect eats the leaves of a toxic plant called milkweed. As it undergoes metamorphosis to become a butterfly it stores those toxins and becomes poisonous to eat!
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: This orange and black butterfly that migrates through California every year.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Monarch butterflies migrate from their summer breeding grounds in northeastern U.S. and Canada down to Mexico to escape the cold winter. Monarch Butterflies can travel up to 100 miles per day during their 3,000-mile migration south.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Thomas Bresson. Taken on August 31, 2009. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:ComputerHotline_-_Danaus_plexippus_(by)_(3).jpg

GameSequence.Clue: These marine mammals can migrate over 13,000 miles along the west coast of North America every year. Adult males can grow to 13 feet long and up to 5,000 lbs, battling each other for dominance on sandy beaches during mating season.
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: Males have a distinctly large nose or “proboscis” they can inflate that resembles an elephant trunk.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Elephant seals will dive thousands of feet under the ocean for hours at a time to hunt for fish, squid, and octopuses. All elephant seals in the U.S. and Mexico are descended from a small group of individuals that survived being hunted to near extinction in the 1800s for their valuable blubber.
GameSequence.Credit: "Mating scene with elevated Alpha Male" by Mike Baird. Taken on January 31, 2009. https://www.flickr.com/photos/72825507@N00/3242515873

GameSequence.Clue: This structure is actually created by colonies of small animals called polyps that are related to jellyfish and anemones. The animals create a hard limestone exoskeleton that can stick together with its neighbors to form structures from a few inches wide to dozens of feet wide and over 10 feet tall!
GameSequence.AdditionalHint: Large patches of these structures together are called reefs.
GameSequence.CorrectMessage: Coral reefs are vital to our planet’s health, creating habitats for a huge diversity of marine life including fish, sponges, oysters, clams, sea stars and urchins. Coral polyps usually have clear bodies. The vibrant colors you see in coral reefs and aquariums are due to algae that grow in the polyps tissue and benefit from a symbiotic relationship with the coral polyps. The algae removes the coral’s waste and uses it to photosynthesize (make its own food), and the coral uses the oxygen and carbohydrates produced by photosynthesis to build its exoskeleton.
GameSequence.Credit: Photo by Jadhav Vikram. Taken on June 5, 2017. https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Coral_reef_fish_swim_above_the_coral_slope.jpg
